page.title: List of reportedly haunted locations in Colombia

revision.text:
There are numerous reportedly haunted places in [[Colombia]]. This list is alphabetized by province or territory of these places and then alphabetically within each province or territory.
==Antioquia== *'''[[La Catedral]], Medellín''': A short-lived prison, built to incarcerate [[Pablo Escobar]]. Now a monastery<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citytv.com.co/videos/833158/video-espiritus-y-fantasmas-en-la-catedral|editor=CityTv|title=Los fantasmas que rondan la 'Catedral' (In Spanish)|year=2012|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref> *A three floor building located in '''Santa Cruz neighborhood''', part of the northwestern comunes of '''Medellín'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://caracol.com.co/radio/2005/03/01/nacional/1109675220_156886.html|title=Revuelo en barrio de Medellín por "casa embrujada" (In Spanish)|editor=Caracol Radio|year=2005}}</ref>
==Atlántico== *Reports of a ghost bride, in '''La Curva del Diablo''' (The devil's curve) in '''[[Puerto Colombia]]'''. A team from a TV channel were recreating the bride's story claims to have captured footage of the ghost.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elintransigente.com/mundo/2012/10/27/infartante-video-novia-fantasma-puerto-colombia-153996.html|title=El infartante video de la Novia Fantasma de Puerto Colombia (In Spanish)|editor=El Intransigente|year=2012}}</ref>
==Bogotá== [[File:Bogotá,_canal_del_Virrey,_placa_Colmenares.JPG|thumb|Luis Colmenares plaque, El Virrey Park]] [[File:Bog_La_Salle_Candelaria.JPG|thumb|La Salle University, in front of Jose Raimundo Russi House]] [[File:Iglesia_y_convento_de_Las_Aguas_(4).JPG|thumb|Las Aguas Cloister]] [[File:Casa_de_Poesía_Silva_2.jpg|thumb|Patio, Silva House of Poetry]] *'''Bogotá City Hall''' or also known as '''[[Palacio Liévano|Liévano Palace]]'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1503278|editor=Lucevin Gomez|title=EL FANTASMA DE LA ALCALDÍA MAYOR|year=2004|accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1503308|title=UN FANTASMA EN LA ALCALDÍA DE BOGOTÁ|editor=El Tiempo|year=2004}}</ref> *'''[[Bolívar Square]]''': José Raimundo Russi was executed here, and his ghost haunts the square.<ref name="capitalinos">{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1695578|editor=El Tiempo|author=Gloria Helena Rey|title=ESPANTOS CAPITALINOS (In Spanish)|year=2005|accessdate=15 April 2014}}</ref> *An apartment building located in '''[[Chapinero]]''' where [[Campo Elias Delgado]] killed his mother and six of his neighbours, before perpetrating what is known as [[Campo Elias Delgado#Pizzería Pozzetto|The Pozzetto Massacre]].<ref name="patasola">{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-678552|author=Sergio Ocampo, Jorge Meléndez|editor=El Tiempo|year=2001|title=Quién Espantó A La Patasola (In Spanish)|accessdate=15 April 2014|display-authors=etal}}</ref> *A family residence in '''Ciudad Montes''', in [[Puente Aranda]] district.<ref name="urbano">{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-952451|title=TERROR URBANO TAMBIÉN HAY (In Spanish)|author=Jimmy Arias|editor=El Tiempo|year=1999}}</ref> *'''El Virrey Park''', where [[Death of Luis Andres Colmenares|Luis Colmenares]] died under undiscovered circumstances. Strange occurrences have been reported .<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-12180662|title=Reportan extraños fenómenos donde se halló cuerpo de Luis Colmenares (In Spanish)|editor=El Tiempo|year=2012}}</ref> *The '''[[Colombian Institute of Anthropology and History]] headquarters'''<ref name="dosmilseis">{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-2252977|title=Casas embrujadas de La Candelaria (In Spanish)|year=2006|accessdate=23 November 2014}}</ref> *The streets around the campus of '''[[La Salle University, Colombia|La Salle University]]''' host the spectre of a vengeful woman who was rejected by a Spanish priest.<ref name="Stella Monsalve">{{cite web|url=http://portel.bogota.gov.co/archivo/libreria/pdf/fantasmas.pdf|author=Stella Monsalve Gaitán|title=FANTASMAS DE LA CANDELARIA (In Spanish)|year=2008|accessdate=29 March 2014}}</ref> *Under the main altar of '''La Concepción Church''', three knocks are reported to be heard whenever a nun is about to die.<ref name="casahorror">{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1269639|title=LAS CASAS DEL HORROR (In Spanish)|author=Ingrid Mora|editor=El Tiempo|year=2000}}</ref> *'''[[Manuelita Sáenz]] House'''<ref name="uncover">{{cite web|url=http://www.uncovercolombia.com/index.php/en/blog/blog-colombia/item/day-of-the-dead-ghostly-apparitions-in-bogota-s-la-candelaria|title=Day of the Dead: Ghostly Apparitions in Bogota's La Candelaria|editor=Uncover Colombia|year=2014}}</ref> *The '''[[Silva Poetry House]]'''<ref name="elespectador">{{cite web|url=http://www.elespectador.com/noticias/actualidad/los-8-fantasmas-de-candelaria-articulo-393804|editor=El Espectador|title=Los 8 fantasmas de la Candelaria|year=2002|accessdate=15 April 2014}}</ref> *'''La Inmaculada Cemetery''': There is an urban legend of a phantom passenger.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elespectador.com/noticias/actualidad/fantasma-del-taxi-escalofriante-historia-de-halloween-video-384374|title=La fantasma del taxi, escalofriante historia de Halloween (Video) (In Spanish)|editor=El Espectador|year=2012}}</ref> *On the corner of '''Calle de La Esperanza''' and '''Calle de La Parra''' sits a house where legends say horrifying satanic rites took place in. In 1999, a local newspaper reported a security guard found a two-meter tall white human shape on the patio, when he was there alone.<ref name="Stella Monsalve"/> *'''Calle de la Peña''': An old manor in this street has a terrible reputation. Apparently there's a ghost in the patio that had cursed the existence of everyone who has the misfortune to see it. Legend says that even [[Simon Bolívar]] got to see it when he was escaping from a complot to kill him. The husband of the actual owner hung up himself after some encounters with the infamous ghost; he left a note to his wife revealing the horrible secret of the ghost, but the wife refuses to reveal it. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elperiodico.com.co/informe-especial/informe-especial/3052-el-fantasma-de-la-vieja-casona.html|title=El ‘fantasma’ de la vieja casona (In Spanish)|publisher=El Periódico de Bogotá|year=2011}}</ref> *'''Calle del Sol''' (The Street of the Sun) was built in 1917 as a lodge for a religious community, but became the headquarters for the Colombian Intelligence Service (now DAS) in 1945,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lacandelaria.info/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=92:edificio-calle-del-sol&catid=96:edificios&Itemid=75|title=Edificio Calle del Sol|accessdate=15 April 2014}}</ref> which was used to incarcerate and torture prisoners during [[La Violencia]]. Now an apartment complex, some residents report hearing screams, moans, laughs, punches and whippings, preceded by lights and strange fogs.<ref name="elespectador"/> Some workers of a restaurant, also located on the dungeon's location, report toilets flushing by themselves, things changing position on their own, and an invisible force in the kitchen area which pats workers on their backs. Supposedly these are the souls of those who were tortured, or perhaps a witch who was the mother of one of those prisoners.<ref name="metrocuadrado.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.metrocuadrado.com/noticias/ideas-para-viajar/tres-lugares-embrujados-en-bogota-809|title=Tres lugares embrujados en Bogotá (In Spanish)}}</ref> *The '''Casa Sámano Museum''' used to belong to [[Juan Samano|Juan Sámano]], Viceroy of New Granada. Probably one of the most hated figures of Colombian history; in life he used to spit, step on and kick those he did not like, which he has continued doing in the afterlife.<ref name="elespectador"/> Surveillance have felt steps on the second floor and doors which appear to open by themselves.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T1YGyqs34AE#t=26|author=City Noticias|title=SUPUESTO FANTASMA SE APARECE EN EL MUSEO CASA SAMANO (In Spanish)|accessdate=15 April 2014}}</ref> *The '''Gilberto Alzate Avendaño Foundation''' is reported to be haunted by the ghost of Viceroy [[José Manuel de Ezpeleta, 1st Count of Ezpeleta de Beire|José Manuel de Ezpeleta]], nicknamed "The Green Jacket Ghost". Legend says the ghost used to knock three times on a wall on the second floor and then disappear.<ref name="elespectador">{{cite web|url=http://www.elespectador.com/noticias/actualidad/los-8-fantasmas-de-candelaria-articulo-393804|editor=El Espectador|title=Los 8 fantasmas de la Candelaria|year=2002|accessdate=15 April 2014}}</ref><ref name="capitalinos">{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1695578|editor=El Tiempo|author=Gloria Helena Rey|title=ESPANTOS CAPITALINOS (In Spanish)|year=2005|accessdate=15 April 2014}}</ref> *'''Gregario Vásquez de Arce y Ceballos House''' has the benevolent ghost of the owner, who appears in the basement and the patio, wearing a long black cape.<ref name="elespectador"/> *The '''José Caicedo Rojas House''', also known as The Goblin's Mansion, is haunted by a goblin named Baltazar. Legend says the goblin is the spirit of a newborn, who was thrown into the patio's well by his single mother, afraid of being burned at the stake under the laws of the [[Holy Office]].<ref name="Stella Monsalve"/> *The '''Jose Raimundo Russi House''' is where Manuelito Ferro was murdered in front of, with Russi being charged for the crime. Some neighbors have said they hear the screams of Ferro and the sound of his stabbings.<ref name="elespectador"/><ref name="Stella Monsalve"/> *The '''Juan Montúfar House''' has been a boarding house since colonial times, and is still run by Montúfar descendants. Students who have lived in the house have felt presences, steps in the middle of the night, and temperatures drastically dropping.<ref name="Stella Monsalve"/> *'''Las Aguas Cloister''' is a former convent where people claim to hear noises and see shadows in the south-eastern patio, which the nuns used as a burial place.<ref name="capitalinos"/> *'''Palomar del Príncipe Park''' is haunted by a blonde blue-eyed boy, who used to feed the doves 300 years ago, and who now appears at dawn. A legend says that those who are cruel to the doves will be tormented by the soul of the boy.<ref name="elespectador"/> *The '''Rosa Florida House''' is haunted by General Sardá, who was loyal to [[Simón Bolívar]], and who manifests himself with the sound of his boots stepping on the sidewalks.<ref name="elespectador"/> *The '''Calle 100 Bridge''' that crosses over carrera Séptima, where some local cab drivers avoid to pass. Legend says some of them got scared by the ghost of a nun who was killed near to this spot. <ref name="calle100">{{cite web|url=https://www.publimetro.co/co/bogota/2016/08/23/historia-fantasma-puente-calle-100.html|editor=Publimetro|author=Pamela Lopez|title=La historia del fantasma del puente de la calle 100|year=2016|accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>
==Bolívar== [[File:NAVAL MUSEUM OF THE CARIBBEAN, CARTAGENA, COLOMBIA.jpg|thumb|Naval Museum of the Caribbean, Cartagena]]
*'''Naval Museum of the Caribbean, [[Cartagena, Colombia|Cartagena]]''': A tourist took a photograph of the ghost of an old man, but nothing appeared on the building's security cameras.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elheraldo.co/region/en-el-naval-de-cartagena-hay-mas-fantasmas-que-piezas-de-museo|editor=elheraldo.co|title=En el Naval de Cartagena hay más fantasmas que piezas de museo|year=2011|accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> *The former '''San Pablo Psychiatric Hospital''' in '''Cartagena'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://caracol.com.co/radio/2009/03/26/regional/1238067660_784867.html|title=Fantasmas atormentan a trabajadores del antiguo hospital psiquiátrico de Cartagena (In Spanish)|editor=Caracol Radio|year=2009}}</ref> *'''Santa Clara Hotel, Cartagena''': Founded in 1621, this large building is a former monastery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/colombia/otras-ciudades/hotel-santa-clara-de-cartagena-el-mejor-de-colombia/16400299|title=La leyenda del convento que se convirtió en un hotel de clase mundial (In Spanish)|author=Valentina Obando|editor=El Tiempo|year=2015}}</ref> The ghost stories made it harder for the renovator to get and keep workers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-3168126|title=Cartagena y sus fantasmas (In Spanish)|author=Ingrid Mora|editor=El Tiempo|year=2008}}</ref>
==Boyacá== *'''Las Nieves Church, [[Tunja]]''': A legend of a levitating lantern, making a trip between Las Nieves and the Metropolitan Cathedral.<ref name="luisangel">{{cite web|url=http://www.banrepcultural.org/blaavirtual/folclor/pueboy/pueboy8.htm|title=EL PUEBLO BOYACENSE Y SU FOLCLOR (In Spanish)|author=Javier Ocampo López|editor=Corporación de Promoción Cultural de Boyacá|year=1977}}</ref> *'''San Francisco de Asis Church, Tunja''': Claims of a large dog that barks and howls at late hours, dragging chains and bright eyes.<ref name="luisangel"/> *There are stories that old town in '''Tunja''' was haunted by the ghosts of Franciscan and Dominican monks.<ref name="luisangel"/> *'''Los Cojines del Zaque''', a [[muisca]] sanctuary located in the hills of Tunja, where some strange phenomena has been reported. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bluradio.com/sociedad/lugares-poseidos-y-fantasmas-en-colombia-111006|editor=Blu Radio|title=Lugares poseídos y fantasmas en Colombia|year=2016|accessdate=16 October 2018}}</ref>
==Caldas==
*'''Cerro de Oro, [[Manizales]]''': A story that if [[candy]] is placed over a car, ghosts of children will approach the car and take the candy. <ref name="manizales">{{cite web|url=http://www.lapatria.com/manizales/historias-reales-de-mitos-urbanos-en-manizales-20391|title=Historias reales de mitos urbanos en Manizales (In Spanish)|publisher=La Patria|author=Mónica Franco|date= November 25, 2012}}</ref> *'''La Argentina neighborhood, Manizales''': A story of a horseman who used to provide milk to the neighbors whose ghost allegedly still gallops around the streets.<ref name="manizales"/> *'''Manizales City Centre''': Karina Albornoz was a [[greengrocer]] killed by her husband in 1941, who allegedly haunts the building.<ref name="manizales"/> *'''San Jorge neighborhood, Manizales''': A lady who wears red heels is said to haunt an old house in this neighborhood.<ref name="manizales"/>
==Caquetá== *An old manor, known by locals as the '''Horror House''', located between '''La Salle School''' and '''La Consolata neighborhood''' in '''[[Florencia, Caquetá|Florencia]]'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.las2orillas.co/una-noche-en-la-casa-del-terror-del-caqueta/|title=Una noche en la casa del terror del Caquetá (In Spanish)|publisher=Las 2 Orillas|author= Edilberto Valencia|date= June 12, 2016}}</ref>
==Cauca== *'''Párraga, [[La Sierra, Cauca|La Sierra]]''': stones were thrown to the township's roofs, which was blamed on a deaf-mute woman.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1544881|title=LAS PIEDRAS EMBRUJADAS DE PÁRRAGA (In Spanish)|author=Adriana Espinel|editor=El Tiempo|year=2004}}</ref>
==Cundinamarca== [[File:Castillomarroquínfoto.JPG|thumb|Marroquín Castle]] *'''Marroquín Castle, Chía''': A tall woman dressed in black, called "La Zancona", is one of several ghosts claimed to inhabit the location.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1301872|author=Francisco Quintero|editor=El Tiempo|title=CASTILLO DE LA RUMBA (In Spanish)|year=2000|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref> *'''[[Tequendama Falls Museum|Salto de Tequendama House]], [[San Antonio del Tequendama]]''': A former hotel near the [[Tequendama Falls]], a place with a high rate of suicides. There has been claims of a headless man seen walking around the terrace or watching from the windows.<ref name="orillas">{{cite web|title=Las casas malditas en Colombia y otros lugares terroríficos del mundo (In Spanish)|url=http://www.las2orillas.co/las-casas-malditas-en-colombia-de-otros-lugares-terrorificos-del-mundo/|author=Iván Gallo|editor=Las 2 Orillas|date=October 30, 2014}}</ref> *'''Siberia, [[La Calera, Colombia|La Calera]]''': Visitors are said to have heard a children singing, though there could be a natural explanation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.noticiascaracol.com/colombia/supuesto-coro-de-ninos-asusta-en-pueblo-fantasma-de-cundinamarca|title=Supuesto Coro de Niños asusta en pueblo fantasma de Cundinamarca (In Spanish)|editor=Noticias Caracol|year=2015}}</ref>
==Huila== *'''La Jagua, [[Garzón (Colombia)|Garzón]]''': Believed to be haunted by witches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/colombia/otras-ciudades/pueblos-insolitos-la-jagua-el-pueblo-donde-hasta-el-alcalde-dice-creer-en-las-brujas/16090555|title=La Jagua, el pueblo donde hasta el alcalde dice creer en las brujas (In Spanish)|editor= El Tiempo|author=Fabio Arenas Jaimes|year=2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://diariodelhuila.com/opinion/la-brujas-de-la-jagua-cdgint20150108075132196|title=La brujas de La Jagua (In Spanish)|editor= El Diario del Huila|author=Diógenes Díaz Carabalí|year=2015}}</ref>
==Magdalena== [[File:Casa del diablo en Cienaga Colombia.JPG|thumb|Manuel Varela House]] *'''Manuel Varela House''' also known as '''The Devil's house''', '''[[Ciénaga, Magdalena|Ciénaga]]''': An abandoned republican mansion, home to a physician Manuel Varela, who legend says sacrificed a souls to the devil in return for wealth. Witches, ghosts of workers, a gold-toothed black boy who smokes tobacco while riding a tricycle, and even the devil himself are said to haunt the mansion and its surrounding grounds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1359664|editor=El Tiempo|author=LEONARDO HERRERA DELGHAMS|title=EL DIABLO TIENE CASA EN CIÉNAGA (In Spanish)|year=2002|accessdate=16 April 2014}}</ref>
==Meta==
*'''El Manantial neighborhood, [[Villavicencio]]''': Unknown if it's a goblin or the spirit of a boy who appeared dead next to a wetland, many people have felt attacked by this presence or simply get to see unusual events inside their houses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-5569688|title='Fantasma infantil' asusta, al parecer, a habitantes del barrio Manantial de Villavicencio (In Spanish)|publisher=Llano Siete Días|date= July 1, 2009}}</ref>
==Norte de Santander== * An old blue house built in '''El Páramo neighborhood''', in '''[[Cúcuta]]''' was the home of Egon Bernhard, a [[Nazism|nazi]] sympathizer who arrived from [[Germany]] before the [[Second World War]]. Bernhard was found shot dead in 1987 and now his grandson lives in the house, which now threatens to fall down. The grandson claims a girl haunts the upper floors. He has heard her moaning, so he tries to calm her with a cup of water but sometimes the task isn't a success and the girls get rebellious. Sometimes she looks for him in his bedroom and approaches him slowly, just to vanish when she gets really closer to his bed.<ref name="orillas"/> *'''La Gabarra, [[Tibú]]''': The Restrepo family home was taken by the [[United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia|AUC]] and turned into a headquarter where huge parties took place, but also ominous crimes where prisoners were tortured, hanged with hooks and quartered with chainsaws. The new owner counts more than 150 prisoners who died there during four years so he suspects the number of corpses buried inside the house is also huge. For him and his family it's only possible to sleep during daytime since they claim that during nights they have seen two black dogs walking around the two cells built in the patio. They also claim to have heard screams, moans and whispers and seen moving shadows.<ref name="orillas"/> *'''[[Ocaña, Colombia|Ocaña]]''': Antón García de Bonilla, a legendary landlord, still lures in the town old streets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canalrcnmsn.com/content/fantasma_de_legendario_terrateniente_ronda_por_oca%C3%B1a|title=Fantasma de legendario terrateniente ronda por Ocaña (VIDEO) (In Spanish)|publisher=Canal RCN|date=April 10, 2013}}</ref>
==Quindío==
*'''[[Armenia, Colombia|Armenia]] City Hall''': The spirits of some of the previous workers scare the surveillance, specially on the parking lots, the fourth and the sixth floors and the restrooms. Mass offered several times to put those souls to rest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.terra.com.co/actualidad/articulo/html/acu17295-fantasmas-los-nuevos-inquilinos-de-la-alcaldia-de-armenia.htm|title=Fantasmas, los nuevos inquilinos de la Alcaldía de Armenia (In Spanish)|publisher=Terra.com.co|year=2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mensual.prensa.com/mensual/contenido/2008/12/17/uhora/curio_2008121712081853.shtml|title=Organizan misa en Alcaldía para sacar a fantasmas|publisher=Prensa.com|date=December 17, 2008}}</ref> *'''Banco Popular, Armenia''': A former bank manager came out to write about the strange occurrences that happened in the bank thirty years ago. One of the guards told him about hearing heavy footsteps, coughings, desks being opened and closed. Suddenly the sounds became more prequent, now adding voices and bangs. Another guard reported to watch a typewriter operating by itself. Apparently, when the superiors made fun of the ghost story, The first guard told the manager the spirit got angry and locked itself inside the guards' room. The guard decided to deal with the ghost, throwing holy water at it. A violent stream blew itself to the adjacent wall, and the phenomenons never happened again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elespectador.com/opinion/el-fantasma-del-banco|title=El fantasma del banco |author=Gustavo Páez Escobar|editor=El Espectador|year=2012}}</ref>
==Risaralda==
*'''Diocesano School, [[Dosquebradas]]''': A nun roaming in the corridors, a man dressed in black and a playful girl on the second floor have been seen in the building at late hours.<ref name="diocesano">{{cite web|url=http://www.eldiario.com.co/seccion/OPINION/los-fantasmas-del-diocesano-090731.html|title=Los fantasmas del Diocesano (In Spanish)|publisher=El Diario del Otún|date=August 1, 2009}}</ref> *'''Hernando Vélez Marulanda neighborhood, [[Pereira, Colombia|Pereira]]''': A school in this neighborhood has its own ghost nun who appears in the restrooms. Suspicions are that the presence is indicating the site of a ''guaca''.<ref name="diocesano"/> * A [[Haunted attraction (simulated)|Horror House]] in '''Pereira''' appears to be haunted for real. The owners, a pair of brothers, found an abandoned old house; they found it so scary that they decided to put the attraction there. When the attraction opened, the brothers had a hard time hiring guards, since some of them quit when they claimed to have heard strange steps and moving things.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eldiario.com.co/anteriores/29-10-2011/casa-de-terror-con-espanto-propio111028.html|title=Casa de terror con espanto propio (In Spanish)|editor=El Diario del Otún|year=2011}}</ref>
==Santander== [[File:Capilla las nieves.jpg|thumb|Las Nieves Chapel]] *A 100 years old house in '''[[Bucaramanga]]''', site of a guaca and where a lot of paranormal activity scared three generations of a family. {{Redirect|Plunder}} {{Redirect|Ransack|the Transformers character|Ransack (Transformers)}} [[File:Pluenderung der Judengasse 1614.jpg|thumb|The plundering of the [[Frankfurter Judengasse]], 22 August 1614]] '''Looting''', also referred to as '''sacking''', '''ransacking''', '''plundering''', '''despoiling''', '''despoliation''', and '''pillaging''', is the indiscriminate taking of goods by force as part of a military or political victory, or during a catastrophe, such as [[war]],<ref name="BBC_Baghdad_protests">{{cite news | title = Baghdad protests over looting | work = BBC News | publisher = BBC | date = 2003-04-12 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/2941733.stm | accessdate = 2010-10-22}}</ref> [[natural disaster]] (where law and civil enforcement are temporarily ineffective),<ref name="BBC_Americas_looting">{{cite news | title = World: Americas Looting frenzy in quake city |publisher = BBC News| date = 1999-01-28 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/262848.stm | accessdate = 2010-10-22}}</ref> or [[rioting]].<ref name="BBC_Argentine">{{cite news | title = Argentine president resigns |publisher = BBC News| date = 2001-12-21 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/1722584.stm | accessdate = 2010-10-22}}</ref> The term is also used in a broader sense to describe egregious instances of [[theft]] and [[embezzlement]], such as the "plundering" of private or public assets by governments.<ref name="loot_def_dict">{{cite web | title = Definition of the word loot | work = Dictionary.com | publisher = Dictionary.com, LLC | year = 2010 | url = http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/loot | accessdate = }}</ref>
The proceeds of all these activities can be described as '''booty''', '''loot''', '''plunder''', '''spoils''', or '''pillage'''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dictionary.com/browse/looting?s=t|title=the definition of looting|website=Dictionary.com|access-date=2016-12-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dictionary.com/browse/booty|title=Booty - Define Booty at Dictionary.com|publisher=}}</ref> [[File:2011 London riots.jpg|thumb|Looters attempting to enter a cycle shop in North London during the [[2011 England riots]]]]
In [[armed conflict]], pillage is prohibited by [[international law]], and constitutes a [[war crime]].<ref name="ICRC">[https://ihl-databases.icrc.org/customary-ihl/eng/docs/v1_rul_rule52 Rule 52. Pillage is prohibited.], ''Customary IHL Database'', [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] (ICRC)/[[Cambridge University Press]].</ref>
==Looting by type==
===In armed conflict=== [[File:Spaanse Furie - De plundering van Mechelen door de hertog van Alba in 1572 (Frans Hogenberg).jpg|thumb|The sacking and looting of [[Mechelen]] by the Spanish troops led by the [[Fernando Álvarez de Toledo, 3rd Duke of Alba|Duke of Alba]], 2 October 1572]]
Looting by a victorious army during war has been common practice throughout recorded history. For foot soldiers, it was viewed as a way to supplement their often meagre income<ref name=hsc>Hsi-sheng Chi, ''Warlord politics in China, 1916–1928'', Stanford University Press, 1976, {{ISBN|0-8047-0894-0}}, str. 93</ref> and was part of the celebration of victory. On higher levels, the proud exhibition of loot was an integral part of the typical [[Roman triumph]], and [[Genghis Khan]] was not unusual in proclaiming that the greatest happiness was "to vanquish your enemies ... to rob them of their wealth".<ref>Henry Hoyle Howorth [https://books.google.com/books?id=e4PErdXlLhwC&lpg=PA110&pg=PA110#v=onepage&f=false ''History of the Mongols from the 9th to the 19th Century: Part 1 the Mongols Proper and the Kalmyks''], Cosimo Inc. 2008.</ref>
In warfare in ancient times, the spoils of war included the defeated populations, which were often [[enslavement|enslaved]]. The women and children were often absorbed into the victorious country's population.<ref>John K. Thorton, ''African Background in American Colonization'', in ''The Cambridge economic history of the United States'', Stanley L. Engerman, Robert E. Gallman (ed.), Cambridge University Press, 1996, {{ISBN|0-521-39442-2}}, p. 87. "African states waged war to acquire slaves [...] raids that appear to have been more concerned with obtaining loot (including slaves) than other objectives."</ref><ref>Sir John Bagot Glubb, ''The Empire of the Arabs'', Hodder and Stoughton, 1963, p.283. "...thousand Christian captives formed part of the loot and were subsequently sold as slaves in the markets of Syria".</ref> In other pre-modern societies, objects made of precious metals were the preferred target of war looting, largely because of their easy portability. In many cases looting was an opportunity to obtain treasures that otherwise would not have been obtainable. Since the 18th century, [[looted art|works of art]] have increasingly become a popular target. In the 1930s and even more so during [[World War II]], [[Nazi Germany]] engaged in large scale and organized [[Nazi plunder|looting of art and property]].<ref>{{pl icon}} J. R. Kudelski, ''Tajemnice nazistowskiej grabieży polskich zbiorów sztuki'', Warszawa 2004.</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/2291481.stm | work=BBC News | title=Nazi loot claim 'compelling' | date=October 2, 2002 | accessdate=May 11, 2010}}</ref>
Looting, combined with poor [[military discipline]], has occasionally been an army's downfall.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} In other cases, for example the [[Wahhabi sack of Karbala]], loot has financed further victories.<ref>Wayne H. Bowen, [https://books.google.com/books?id=S6J2Q3TlJpMC&pg=PA73&lpg=PA73&source=bl&ots=z7xkfvrX_x&sig=yg1NCeie86areM74Tp0N2ROwUf8&hl=en&ei=f4cCTbnlLsL38AaO_dTrAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBcQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&f=false ''The History of Saudi Arabia''], Greenwood Publishing Group, 2008, p. 73. {{ISBN|0-313-34012-9}}</ref> Not all looters in wartime are conquerors; the looting of [[Vistula Land]] by its retreating defenders in 1915<ref>{{pl icon}} Andrzej Garlicki, ''Z dziejów Drugiej Rzeczypospolitej'', Wydawnictwa Szkolne i Pedagogiczne, 1986, {{ISBN|83-02-02245-4}}, p. 147</ref> was among the factors sapping the loyalty of [[Poland in World War I]]. Local civilians can also take advantage of a breakdown of order to loot public and private property, such as took place at the [[National Museum of Iraq]] in the course of the [[Iraq War]] in 2003.<ref>STEVEN LEE MYERS, [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/24/world/middleeast/24museum.html Iraq Museum Reopens Six Years After Looting], New York Times, February 23, 2009</ref> [[Leo Tolstoy|Tolstoy]]'s novel ''[[War and Peace]]'' describes widespread looting by [[Moscow]]'s citizens before [[Napoleon]]'s troops enter the city, and by [[Grande Armée|French troops]] elsewhere.
====Prohibited under international law==== In [[armed conflict]], pillage is prohibited by both [[customary international law]] and by [[treaty]].<ref name="ICRC"/> The prohibition against pillage was recognized in the [[Lieber Code]], Brussels Declaration (1874), and Oxford Manual.<ref name="ICRC"/> The [[Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907]] ([[Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict|modified in 1954]]) obliges military forces not only to avoid destruction of enemy property, but to provide protection to it.<ref name=hague>Barbara T. Hoffman, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yvXTcGC5CwQC&pg=PA57 ''Art and Cultural Heritage: Law, Policy, and Practice''], Cambridge University Press, 2006, p. 57. {{ISBN|0-521-85764-3}}</ref> Article 8 of the [[Statute of the International Criminal Court]] provides that in international warfare, the "pillaging a town or place, even when taken by assault," is a [[war crime]].<ref name="ICRC"/> In the aftermath of [[World War II]], a number of war criminals were prosecuted for pillage. Several people have been prosecuted by the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]] for pillage.<ref name="ICRC"/>
The [[Fourth Geneva Convention]] of 1949 explicitly prohibits the looting of civilian property during wartime.<ref name="ICRC"/><ref name=gen>E. Lauterpacht, C. J. Greenwood, Marc Weller, [https://books.google.com/books?id=5xVSkGtcT5YC&pg=PA154 ''The Kuwait Crisis: Basic Documents''], Cambridge University Press, 1991, p. 154. {{ISBN|0-521-46308-4}}</ref>
Theoretically, to prevent such looting, unclaimed property is moved to the custody of the [[Custodian of Enemy Property]], to be handled until being returned to its owner.
===Archaeological removals=== {{further information|Grave robbery}} The term "looting" is also sometimes used to refer to [[antiquities]] being removed from countries by unauthorized people, either domestic people breaking the law seeking monetary gain, or by foreign nations, which are usually more interested in prestige or previously, "scientific discovery". An example of this might be the removal of the contents of Egyptian tombs which were transported to museums in Europe.<ref name="pyramid">{{cite news |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2006/10/061024-hawass.html |publisher=National Geographic News |title=Egypt's Antiquities Chief Combines Passion, Clout to Protect Artifacts |date=October 24, 2006 }}</ref> Other examples include the obelisks of Pharaoh [[Amenhotep II]], in the (Oriental Museum, [[University of Durham]], United Kingdom), Pharaoh [[Ptolemy IX]], ([[Philae]] Obelisk, in Wimborne, Dorset, United Kingdom). Whether this constitutes "looting" is a debated point, with other parties pointing out that the Europeans were usually given permission of some sort, and that many of the treasures wouldn't have been discovered at all if the Europeans hadn't funded and organized the expeditions or digs that located them. Many of these antiquities have already been returned to their country of origin voluntarily.
===Looting of industry=== In the aftermath of the [[World War II|Second World War]], Soviet forces systematically plundered the [[Soviet occupation zone]] of Germany, including the [[Recovered Territories]] which were to be transferred to Poland. They sent valuable industrial equipment, infrastructure and whole factories to the Soviet Union.<ref name="IPN-MM">{{cite web|url=http://www.ipn.gov.pl/biuletyn/13/biuletyn02_2.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050321165047/http://www.ipn.gov.pl/biuletyn/13/biuletyn02_2.html |title=MIĘDZY MODERNIZACJĄ A MARNOTRAWSTWEM |archivedate=2005-03-21 |publisher=[[Institute of National Remembrance]] |language=Polish }} See also [http://www.niniwa2.cba.pl/komunizm_gospodarka_prl_ipn.htm other copy online] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070426011453/http://www.niniwa2.cba.pl/komunizm_gospodarka_prl_ipn.htm |date=2007-04-26 }}</ref><ref name="IPN-Ś">{{cite web|url=http://www.ipn.gov.pl/biuletyn/4/biuletyn4_51.html|title=ARMIA CZERWONA NA DOLNYM ŚLĄSKU|publisher=[[Institute of National Remembrance]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050321233124/http://www.ipn.gov.pl/biuletyn/4/biuletyn4_51.html|archivedate=2005-03-21|language=Polish}}</ref>
==Measures against looting following disasters== [[File:053 French Foreign Legion.JPG|thumb|[[Military of Côte d'Ivoire|FAFN]] soldier caught by French Foreign Legion troops.]]
During a disaster, police and military are sometimes unable to prevent looting when they are overwhelmed by humanitarian or combat concerns, or cannot be summoned due to damaged communications infrastructure. Especially during natural disasters, some people find themselves forced to take what is not theirs in order to survive. How to respond to this, and where the line between unnecessary "looting" and necessary "scavenging" lies, is often a dilemma for governments.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/136582.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Indonesian food minister tolerates looting | date=July 21, 1998 | accessdate=May 11, 2010}}</ref> In other cases, looting may be tolerated or even encouraged by governments for political or other reasons.

Egypt Asks Germany for a Majestic Loan'' by Stan Parchin (June 17, 2006) [http://arthistory.about.com/b/2006/06/17/will-nefertiti-return-to-egypt-for-a-brief-visit.htm about.com]</ref>]] [[File:Iraqi Looters in the Archaeological site of Isin 1.jpg|thumb|[[Iraqi people|Iraqi]] looters in the archaeological site of [[Isin]]]]
* Around the same time of the [[Hyksos]] invasion and [[Second Intermediate Period of Egypt|occupation of Egypt]] (1650 BC – 1550 BC), Hebrew tradition has it that both Abraham and Moses were given property of Egypt by God. Yet in Exodus, God uses the [[Plagues of Egypt|plagues]] as an act of mercy to bring a knowledge of himself to Israel, Pharaoh, the Egyptians, and to the ends of the earth."<ref>Joel Stevens Allen, ''The Despoliation of Egypt: In Pre-Rabbinic, Rabbinic and Patristic Traditions'', pg. 128, 2008, [[Brill Publishers|Brill Academic Pub]], {{ISBN|90-04-16745-5}}.</ref> See [[Iconoclasm#Ancient era|Hyksos Iconoclasm]] and [[Lech-Lecha#Second reading .E2.80.93 Genesis 12:14.E2.80.9313:4|Genesis 13:2]] and [[Lech-Lecha#Sixth reading .E2.80.93 Genesis 15:7.E2.80.9317:6|Genesis 15:14]] and [[Bo (parsha)#Sixth reading .E2.80.93 Exodus 12:29.E2.80.9351|Exodus 12:36]]. * Following the death of [[Valentinian III]] in 455, the [[Vandals]] invaded and [[Sack of Rome (455)|extensively looted the city of Rome]]. *In 870 AD, the Byzantine city of [[Melite (ancient city)|Melite]] (now [[Mdina]], [[Malta]]) was [[Siege of Melite (870)|captured]] by the [[Aghlabids]] under Sawāda Ibn Muḥammad. The city was destroyed, its churches looted and its population massacred. Marble from the city's churches was used to build the castle of [[Sousse]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Brincat |first1=Joseph M. |title=New Light on the Darkest Age in Malta's History |url=http://melitensiawth.com/incoming/Index/The%20Arabs%20in%20Malta/1995proc%20Malta%20870-1054%20by%20J.M.%20Brincat.pdf |website=melitensiawth.com |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Z5HkRHsR?url=http://melitensiawth.com/incoming/Index/The%20Arabs%20in%20Malta/1995proc%20Malta%20870-1054%20by%20J.M.%20Brincat.pdf |archivedate=6 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * [[Mahmud of Ghazni]] repeatedly plundered the temple cities of [[Somnath]], [[Mathura]], [[Kannauj]] etc. of India between 1000 A.D and 1027 A.D. * After the [[Siege of Constantinople (1204)|siege of Constantinople in 1204]] during the [[Fourth Crusade]], the crusaders looted the city and transferred its riches to Italy. * Roman Catholic troops of Imperial Field Marshal [[Johann Tserclaes, Count of Tilly]] committed the [[Sack of Magdeburg]] in 1631. Magdeburg's civilian population was quickly reduced from 30,000 to 5,000, giving rise to a new term in German for annihilation by atrocities: "Magdeburgization". * In 1664 the Maratha leader [[Shivaji]] sacked and looted [[Surat]]. * Between 1804 and 1814 [[Napoleon Bonaparte]] engaged in massive looting throughout Europe and Africa. * In 1812, British and Portuguese soldiers sacked the Spanish city of [[Badajoz]] after they had [[Siege of Badajoz (1812)|captured it by siege]]. It was three days before the men were brought back into order. * In 1860, [[Second Opium War#Second Phase|European allied forces]] burned and looted the [[Old Summer Palace#Destruction|Yuan Ming Yuan]] in Beijing, and in 1900, the European [[Eight-Nation Alliance]] looted Beijing when they invaded China to put down the [[Boxer Rebellion#Aftermath|Boxer Uprising]].<ref>{{cite book |last = Hevia, James Louis |first = |year = 2003 |title = English Lessons: The Pedagogy of Imperialism in Nineteenth-Century China |publisher = Duke University Press; Hong Kong University Press| location = Durham; Hong Kong|url= |isbn = 0-8223-3151-9|ref = harv}}.</ref> The extent to which Europeans looted is challenged by more recent evidence from Noel du Boulay, commanding officer in charge of security at the Summer Palace during the Boxer rebellion, who records that the Russians had already looted the Palace before the Europeans assumed responsibility. On 7 October 1900 he officially reports the condition of the Palace as he first encountered it. One of Du Boulay's main duties was to prevent further looting. An extensive catalogue of items in the palace was formally agreed with Shih Hsu, President of the Board of Ceremonies and Comptroller of the Imperial household when the Palace was handed back on 14 September 1901.<ref>{{cite book |last = Du Boulay, F.R.H. |first = |year = 2011 |title = Servants of Empire: An Imperial Memoir of a British Family |publisher = I.B Tauris | location = London; New York | url = | isbn = 978-1-84885-571-7| ref = }}.</ref> * During [[World War II]], [[Nazi Germany]] engaged in looting, particularly by Nazi military units known as the [[Kunstschutz]] ("Art Protection"). The [[Soviet Army]] also operated [[World War II looting of Poland|official trophy brigades]] to loot Germany and the Eastern European countries occupied by Germany (such as Poland). In Asia, the [[Empire of Japan]], through the [[Imperial Japanese Army]], also engaged in massive and systematic looting of valuables. The exact amount of looting during [[World War II]] will never be known, but it is estimated to be worth hundreds of billions of [[United States dollar|dollars]]. See: ** [[Baldin Collection]] ** [[Nazi plunder]] ** [[Yamashita's gold]]

Down|first1=Simon|last1=Romero|first2=Marc|last2=Lacey|date=17 January 2010|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> * During the [[2011 London riots]], gangs of youths undertook looting in a number of areas across the capital.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14450248 | work=BBC News | title=Further riots in London as violence spreads across England | date=August 9, 2011}}</ref> It has been suggested that rioting may have been organised,<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/aug/07/trouble-enfield-organised | location=London | work=The Guardian | first1=Paul | last1=Lewis | first2=Matthew | last2=Taylor | first3=Ben | last3=Quinn | title=Second night of violence in London – and this time it was organised | date=August 8, 2011}}</ref> but it is unclear by whom, and to what end. London had previously been subjected to looting following the [[1981 Brixton riot|Brixton riot of 1981]], and by gangs of youths who took advantage of war damage during the Second World War.<ref>MacKay, Robert (2002). [https://books.google.com/books?id=5FiLit0-N-kC&lpg=PA85&pg=PA84#v=onepage&f=false ''Half the Battle: Civilian Morale in Britain During the Second World War'']. Manchester University Press. p. 84. {{ISBN|0-7190-5894-5}}.</ref> The 2011 London looting was copied on subsequent nights in other cities around England, including [[Manchester]], [[Liverpool]] and [[Birmingham]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14460554 | work=BBC News | title=UK riots: Trouble erupts in English cities | date=August 10, 2011}}</ref> * During 2015 in [[Baltimore, Maryland]], after the funeral of [[Death of Freddie Gray|Freddie Gray]], looting and rioting took place in the Mondawmin neighborhood where the funeral had taken place.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/28/us/baltimore-freddie-gray.html | work=The New York Times | title=Baltimore Enlists National Guard and a Curfew to Fight Riots and Looting | date=April 27, 2015}}</ref> * In 2018, researchers and archaeologists urged [[Albania]] to protect underwater [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] and [[Rome|Roman]] artifacts and [[shipwreck]]s. They were in danger of falling prey to looters or treasure hunters if not properly protected. Some [[amphorae]] have already been looted and are frequently seen decorating restaurants along the Albanian coastline.<ref>[https://www.thenationalherald.com/206515/archaeologists-urge-albania-to-protect-underwater-greek-roman-artifacts/ Archaeologists Urge Albania to Protect Underwater Greek & Roman Artifacts]</ref><ref>[http://www.arabnews.com/node/1333206/art-culture Archaeologists urge Albania to protect underwater heritage]</ref><ref>[http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/looters-plunder-albanias-sunken-treasures-138999 Looters plunder Albania's sunken treasures]</ref>

'''North African Arabs''' ({{lang-ar|عرب شمال أفريقيا}} "‘Arab Shamal Ifriqiya") or "Maghrebi Arabs" ({{lang-ar|:العرب المغاربة}} "al-‘Arab al-Maghariba") are the inhabitants of the North African [[Maghreb]] region whose native language is a [[dialect of Arabic]] and identify as [[Arab people|Arab]].<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of the World's Minorities|author=Skutsch, C.|date=2013|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=9781135193881|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=yXYKAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA119|page=119|accessdate=2017-01-25}}</ref><ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Global Religion|author1=Juergensmeyer, M.|author2=Roof, W.C.|date=2011|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=9781452266565|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=WwJzAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA935|page=935|accessdate=2017-01-25}}</ref><ref name="google3">{{cite book|title=Historical Dictionary of the name="google4">{{cite book|title=Tunisia|author1=Brown, R.V.|author2=Spilling, M.|date=2008|publisher=Marshall Cavendish Benchmark|isbn=9780761430377|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=3QYLUNEWkYcC&pg=PA74|page=74|accessdate=2017-01-25}}</ref><ref name="google5">{{cite book|title=Libya: From Repression to Revolution: A Record of Armed Conflict and International Law Violations, 2011-2013|author=Bassiouni, M.C.|date=2013|publisher=Brill|isbn=9789004257351|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=_DyOAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA18|page=18|accessdate=2017-01-25}}</ref><ref name="google6">{{cite book|title=The Jews of the Middle East and North Africa in Modern Times|author1=Simon, R.S.|author2=Laskier, M.M.|author3=Reguer, S.|date=2003|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=9780231507592|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=VxEJrEY22egC&pg=PA444|page=444|accessdate=2017-01-25}}</ref> This ethnic identity is a product of the [[Arab conquest of North Africa]] during the [[Arab–Byzantine wars]] and the spread of Islam to Africa.<ref name=Christides>{{cite book|last=Christides|first=Vassilios|title=Byzantine Libya and the march of the Arabs towards the west of North Africa|date=2000|pages=44-64|publisher=British Archaeological Reports, Publications|location=Oxford|isbn=978-1841711331}}</ref> The migration of Arab tribes to North Africa in the 11th century was a major factor in the linguistic and cultural Arabization of the Maghreb region, mainly [[Beni Hassan]], [[Banu Hilal]]<ref name="Weiss">Weiss, Bernard G. and Green, Arnold H.(1987) ''A Survey of Arab History'' American University in Cairo Press, Cairo, p. 129, {{ISBN|977-424-180-0}}</ref><ref>Ballais, Jean-Louis (2000) "Chapter 7: Conquests and land degradation in the eastern Maghreb" [https://books.google.com/books?id=zbA2P0BXeI4C&pg=PA133 p. 133]</ref> and [[Banu Sulaym]].
The descendants of the original Arab settlers who continue to speak [[Arabic language|Arabic]] as a first language currently form the single largest population group in North Africa.<ref name=Shoup>{{cite book|last=Shoup|first=John|title=Ethnic Groups of Africa and the Middle East: An Encyclopedia|date=2011|page=16|publisher=ABC-CLIO, Publishers|location=Santa Barbara|isbn=978-1598843620}}</ref>

====[[Alaouite|Alaouite dynasty]]==== The Alaouite dynasty ({{lang-ar| سلالة العلويين الفيلاليين}}, Sulālat al-ʿAlawiyyīn al-Fīlālīyn) is the current royal family of Morocco. The name comes from ‘Alī ibn Abī Ṭālib, whose descendant, [[Sharif ibn Ali]], became prince of [[Tafilalt]] in 1631. His son [[Al-Rashid of Morocco|Mulay Al-Rashid]] (1664–1672) is credited with uniting and pacifying the country during a turbulent period of Moroccan history. The Alaouite family claim descent from the Islamic prophet [[Muhammad]] through his daughter [[Fatimah|Fāṭimah az-Zahrah]] and her husband ‘Alī ibn Abī Ṭālib.
== Traditions == {{main article|Arab culture}}
===Morocco=== Moroccan women traditionally wear copious amounts of jewelry on their neck, arms, head and ears. Preferably the jewelry should be made from pure gold as this signifies that the family is economically well-off. The jewelry tends to be decorated with different jewels like [[ruby|rubies]], [[olivine]]s, [[Andalucian]] beads, [[pearls]] and [[diamonds]]. The olivines and the pearls are traditionally used in most Maghrebi jewelry. The olivine represents female beauty, and was historically associated with the pre-Islamic goddesses of the Arabian pantheon. The pearls used in the jewelry represent wealth and fortune.
====Weddings==== Brides in Morocco adorn themselves in extensive amounts of jewelry, the amount of jewelry depends on the economic status of the family. Different regions in Morocco have different types of traditional jewelry. Brides in the region of [[Tanger]]-[[Tetouan]] add pearls to their traditional jewelry, whereas brides in the region of [[Fes]] add pheridot jewels and gold. In the [[Sahara]], gold and coloured beads are added to the outfit. Families that can't afford to buy jewelry rent it for the occasion.
The headdresses used in the ceremony also tend to differ depending on the region. The northern region of Morocco, ([[Tanger]]-[[Tetouan]]), use a striped and glittery fabric to cover the bride's head. A headpiece in either silver or gold (depending on the region) is placed over the fabrics and is sometimes decorated with jewels. In the central region, Fes-Meknes, a decorated dark green and golden fabric is used, over it a golden headpiece is placed, decorated with dark green pheridot jewels and pearls hanging down over the face. In the southern region, Western Sahara, the women wear a headpiece decorated with gold pieces and coloured beads that differ from tribe to tribe. The bride's head is covered with a black fabric.

== List of tribes ==
===Morocco=== * [[Azwafit]], a tribe of Bedouin [[Arab]] origin, part of the greater Tekna confederation. Historically the tribe would escort and protect caravans for the payment of a fee known as "Ztata" or "Zfata", whence the name Azwafit. Because they became part of a bigger Berber tribe, the Arab sub-tribes are partially Berberised and speak Berber today. The writer La Chapelle noted that Azwafits counted the following five branches: Ait Ahmed Ou Ali, Ahl Hayin, Mhamd Ait Ait El Khennous, Ait Messaoud Ait Boukko and Ida Ou Louggan.<ref>Azwafit. Historical dictionary of the bedouins. Muhammad Suwaed. 2015</ref> * [[Ahl Rachida]], an [[Arab]] tribe, also referred to as Ouled Sidi Yaakoub. The tribe can trace its lineage to the Islamic prophet [[Muhammad]] through his grandson, [[sharif|Hasan ibn Ali]]. * [[Hyayna]] * [[Hamyane]] * [[Rhamna]] * [[Abda tribe|Abda]], an Arab tribe whose origin dates back to the arrival of the Beni [[Maqil]] tribe at the end of the Merinid era. Historian Eugene Aubin wrote: "The Abda are a powerful tribe, consisting of thirty-thousand cind lights, Arab purment race, they occupy a fertile territory, rich in horses and cattle. It is one of five quasi-Makhzen tribes of Morocco." It consists of three branches, Bhatra, Rabiaa and Ouled Amer.<ref>Historical dictionary of the bedouins. Muhammad Suwaed. 2015</ref> * [[Beni Ahsen tribe|Beni Ahsen]], an Arab-Moroccan tribe, part of Beni Maqil. They settled in the Missour and Almis area around the 16th century, and migrated northwest of the Sefrou region in the 17th century. In the 18th century they were pushed west by the Zemmour tribe, which had migrated north from the south. Today they are located in the region of Rabat and the Atlantic coast.<ref>Historical dictionary of the bedouins. Muhammad Suwaed. 2015</ref> * [[Beni Amir]] * [[Beni Guil]], an Arab tribe that can trace its lineage to the prophet's grandson, [[sharif|Hasan ibn Ali]]. In the 10th century their ancestors were given the right to graze in eastern and western Morocco by the Fatimid ruler Al-Mu'izz li-Din Allah. * [[Beni Mathar]] * [[Beni Hassan]] * [[Maqil]] * [[Beni Khirane]] * [[Beni Zemmour]]

{{expand French|Chiffres de population de la France|date=May 2012}} '''Population without double counting''' is an English translation of the French phrase ''Population sans doubles comptes''.
In [[France]], for the purposes of the [[census]], the [[INSEE]] has defined several population indicators that allow people who live in more than one place to be counted in each place, to study and keep count of population movement. So each commune in France does not have only one figure for the population, but several; for example students may be counted both where they study and where they live when not studying. A parallel may be drawn to English laws that allow students to register and vote in local elections in more than one place.
== How it is measured == The '''population figures of France''' depend on the definition of "French". [[Institut national de la statistique et des études économiques|INSEE]], the French national statistics bureau has two definitions: * All of the ''65,585,857'' people (as of 1 January 2013) who reside in France, including 33,817,227 women and 31,768,630 men which is 235,676 more people than January 1, 2012. This is the definition used most frequently, especially by [[Institut national de la statistique et des études économiques|INSEE]] for censuses that count all people residing in France, regardless of their nationality. ''French'' is the demonym of France, that is to say that people who live in France are called French. The census of people residing in France, regardless of nationality, is provided by [[Institut national de la statistique et des études économiques|INSEE]] under the vocabulary Total population of France. As of <abbr>1</abbr> January 2008, the population of France was 63 753 140 inhabitants residing in [[Metropolitan France|Mainland France]], [[Réunion]], [[Mayotte]], [[Martinique]], [[Guadeloupe]] and [[French Guiana]]. * All of the ''63,379,349'' people as of January 1, 2013 of French nationality (i.e French Passport Holders), whether they live in France or abroad. They are the citizens of the French Republic "without distinction of origin, race, or religion". The [[Civil Code of France|Civil Code]] defines French nationality , the conditions for obtaining it and the rights and duties inherent to it. The number of French (in the sense of "persons having French nationality") is estimated on January 1, 2013 to be 65,585,857 inhabitants minus 3,817,562 foreigners, plus 1,611,054 expatriate French nationals which gives the total number of French Nationals to be 63,379,349.
==Statistical view==
The figures given by [[INSEE]] for a particular commune are : ; Population municipale : a count of the people who live in a house, flat etc. in the commune ; Population comptée à part : those living in a collective or temporary manner (prisoners, soldiers, hospital patients, nuns, monks, students) ; Population totale : the sum of ''population municipale'' and ''population comptée à part'' ; Doubles comptes : a sub-division of ''population comptée à part'', comprising those who have a second residence in another commune and are already counted in that commune's ''population municipale'' ; Population sans doubles comptes : the ''population totale'' minus the ''doubles comptes''<ref name=R2151>{{citation |url=http://www.easydroit.fr/codes-et-lois/TITRE-V-POPULATION-DE-LA-COMMUNE-R-du-Code-general-des-collectivites-territoriales/S45094/ |chapter=Population de la Commune |title=Code géneral des collectives territoriales |accessdate=2009-04-14 |language=French }}</ref>
The ''population sans doubles comptes'' is therefore always no smaller than the ''population municipale'' and no larger than the ''population totale''.
To evaluate the population properly, one should use the ''population sans doubles comptes''.
Since 1999, places with fewer than 10,000 inhabitants have had a census every five years, with one-fifth of the places each year being subject to census.
Since 2004, places with 10,000 inhabitants or more have an annual census of a sample 8% of the population. This is carried out in January and February. A census collector leaves a questionnaire and collects it at a later date.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009|reason=how is the sample decided? e.g. at random}} Since this time, ''population municipale'' and ''population sans doubles comptes'' have had the same meaning.
== Legal aspects == Census results are official by law.
The '''population totale''' is used when applying rules and regulations to budget and finance, in particular in section R2151-2 of the Code of Territorial Collectives.<ref name=R2151/> But the '''population municipale''' determines the size of a council and the scrutiny of municipal elections, R2151-3.<ref name=R2151/>

{{update|date=January 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2015}} {{POV|date=July 2012}} '''Pratibha Mahila Sahakari Bank''' (Pratibha Women Cooperative Bank) was a cooperative bank based in [[Jalgaon]], [[Maharashtra]], India. It was founded in 1973 by [[Pratibha Patil]], who later became [[President of India]], with the objective of empowering women.
Patil was a [[chairperson]] of the bank and also one of its directors, along with many of her relatives.<ref name="kidwai" /> She is one of 34 respondents in an ongoing case before the [[Aurangabad, Maharashtra|Aurangabad]] bench of the [[Bombay High Court]] regarding alleged mismanagement of the bank and misappropriation of funds.<ref>{{cite news |work=Frontline |title=Rough ride |first=Venkitesh |last=Ramakrishnan |date=13 July 2007 |url=http://www.frontline.in/static/html/fl2413/stories/20070713005213300.htm |accessdate=2016-01-13}}</ref>
The [[Reserve Bank of India]] (RBI) revoked the licence of the bank in 2003 after it was found out that the bank had engaged in various irregularities, including illegally waiving interest on loans given to many of Patil's family members.
== Inquiries and closure == The bank was declared "weak" by the RBI in 1995.<ref>Sarin, Ritu (24 June 2007). [http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/pratibha-bank-waived-loans-for-kin-before-rbi-shut-it-down--------/160431/0 "Pratibha bank waived loans for kin before RBI shut it down"]. ''[[The Indian Express]]''. Retrieved 12 January 2016.</ref> An inquiry under the Maharashtra Cooperative Societies Act was ordered in July 2001 and reported that the bank had incurred losses of Rs 1.35 [[crore]]. This led to the resignations of the chairperson and eight directors.{{cn|date=January 2016}} In April 2002, the [[Ministry of Finance (India)|Ministry of Finance]] asked the RBI to inquire into allegations of fund irregularities after receiving a number of complaints from the Cooperative Bank Employees Union and small depositors of the bank.{{cn|date=January 2016}}
In February 2003, the RBI revoked the bank's licence due to concerns relating to serious financial irregularities. Among other points, the RBI noted that the bank's loan policy was suspect and that members of Patil's family, including brothers and nephews, had received favourable treatment regarding loans. Allegations listed by the RBI include a faulty loan policy of the bank and loan interest waivers given to Patil's relatives. It said that there was no-one on the board with knowledge of either management generally or banking in particular.<ref>{{cite news |title=More skeletons in Patil's closet |date=25 June 2007 |url=http://www.ibnlive.com/news/politics/pratibha-rbi-268079.html |work=Ibnlive.com |accessdate=2016-01-13}}</ref> The RBI determined that six of the ten largest loan defaulters were connected to Patil's family,<ref name="ie">{{cite news |last=Kulkarni |first=Dhaval |date=29 June 2007 |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/story/203367.html |title='Tai may become President, what about us who have been cheated?' |work=The Indian Express |accessdate=2016-01-12}}</ref> that the paid-up [[share capital]] was negative and that its gross [[non-performing asset]]s amounted to Rs 391.20 lakh.<ref name="indiatoday" />
== Post-closure events == Many depositors who had been attracted to the bank because of the involvement of Patil lost much of their savings, although the first Rs 1 [[lakh]] of their funds was protected by [[deposit insurance]]. At the time of Patil's nomination for the office of President of India, some of these people, who had still not received the balance of their deposits, alleged that the bank had become a "family fiefdom". Patil's spokespeople said that she had had no involvement in the granting of loans during her period as chairperson.<ref name="ie" /> They said that she had been chairperson for only slightly over a month and that the RBI report made no mention of her.<ref name="kidwai">{{cite book |title=Sonia: A Biography |first=Rasheed |last=Kidwai |edition=Revised |publisher=Penguin Books India |year=2011 |page=169 |isbn=978-0-14341-686-9 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=2CobDtBQVGgC&lpg=PA169 |accessdate=2016-01-13}}</ref>
A High Court writ petition, filed by the banks' depositors and former employees in 2007 at the time of Patil's nomination for president, alleged that the bank collected Rs 4,556 from its employees' wages for victims of the [[Kargil War]] but failed to deposit the amount in the national fund. Other claims included that Patil's brother, Dilip, had misused the bank's telephone service and the bank ignored its remit of primarily loaning to women in order to provide loans for Patils's male relatives. Spokespeople from Patil's political party, the [[Indian National Congress]], denied any involvement by her in these matters, saying that the bank operated satisfactorily until 1993.<ref>{{cite news |work=The Hindu |date=3 July 2007 |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/pil-against-pratibha-candidature/article1865742.ece |title=PIL against Pratibha candidature |accessdate=2016-01-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |work=Ibnlive.com |title=Pratibha's kin default on loans |date=28 June 2007 |url=http://in.news.yahoo.com/070627/211/6hgap.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630084606/http://in.news.yahoo.com/070627/211/6hgap.html |archivedate=30 June 2007 |accessdate=2016-01-13}}</ref> Some local INC members in Jalgaon, however, disagreed with the official line, as did the employees' union. They claimed that Patil had facilitated unsecured loans to her family and arranged waivers of interest despite the poor financial state of the bank after 1995. In total, they said, the familial loans that were defaulted amounted to nearly Rs. 225 lakh.<ref name="indiatoday">{{cite news |title=Embarrassing Choice |first1=Prerana |last1=Thakurdesai |first2=Priya |last2=Sahgal |date=9 July 2007 |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/patil-the-outstanding-choice-for-presidentship/1/155553.html |work=India Today |accessdate=2016-01-13}}</ref>
In 2011, Rajesh Chakrabarti, a faculty member at the [[Indian School of Business]], wrote that the irregularities at Pratibha Mahila Sahakari Bank, along with some other notable problems among [[Urban Co-operative Bank]]s (UCBs), "contributed significantly in eroding the brand value of UCBs" in the early 2000s.<ref>{{cite news |first=Rajesh |last=Chakrabarti |work=Forbes India |url=http://forbesindia.com/printcontent/28382 |date=13 September 2011 |title=The Role of Urban Cooperative Banks in Financial Inclusion |accessdate=2016-01-13}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{refimprove|date=April 2012}} {{Royal house| |surname = Shah Dynasty
शाह वंश |estate = of Nepal |coat of arms = Coat of Arms of Shah dynasty.gif |country = {{Plainlist| *[[Gorkha Kingdom|Kingdom of Gorkha]] *[[Kingdom of Nepal]]}} |titles = {{Plainlist| *King of [[Kaski District|Kaski]] *King of [[Lamjung District|Lamjung]] *King of [[Gorkha Kingdom|Gorkha]] *[[King of Nepal]]}} |founder = [[Kulamandan Khan]] (Shah) |final ruler = [[Gyanendra of Nepal|Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah]] |current head = [[Gyanendra of Nepal|Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah]] |founding year = 16th century |deposition = 28 May 2008 (presently as [[pretender]]) |religion = [[Hinduism]] |ethnicity = [[Thakuri]] }} {{History of Nepal}} '''Shah dynasty''' ({{lang-ne|[[:ne:शाह वंश|शाह वंश]]}}) was the ruling [[Chaubisi rajya|Chaubise]] [[Thakuri]] dynasty from the [[Gorkha Kingdom]] from 1559 to 1768 and later the unified [[Kingdom of Nepal]] from 1768 to 28 May 2008. Shah dynasty traces their historical ancestor to King of Kaski, [[Kulamandan Khan]], whose grandson [[Dravya Shah]] captured the throne of Gorkha from [[Khadka]] kings with the help of accomplices from six resident clans of Gorkha to become the King of Gorkha. ==Origins== The Shah descendants claimed to be of [[Rajput]] origin.{{cite book|author=Karl J. Schmidt|title=An Atlas and Survey of South Asian History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BqdzCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA138|date=20 May 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-47681-8|pages=138–}} However, they are ranked as [[Thakuri]]s.{{cite book|author=Dharam Vir|title=Education and Polity in Nepal: An Asian Experiment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yEHODCDK-8kC&pg=PA56|year=1988|publisher=Northern Book Centre|isbn=978-81-85119-39-7|pages=56–57}} == Coronation of Dravya Shah== [[File:Battle of Ligligkot.jpg|thumb|Battle of Ligligkot, the battle ensured the Dravya Shah as King of Gorkha]] [[Dravya Shah]] was the youngest son of [[Yasho Brahma Shah]], [[Raja]] (King) of Lamjung and grandson of [[Kulamandan Khan]], [[Raja]] (King) of Kaski.{{sfn|Wright|1877|p=278}} He became the king of [[Gorkha]] with the help of accomplices. He ascended the throne of Gorkha on 1559 A.D. 19th century writer Daniel Wright describes the coronation of Dravya Shah as: {{Quote|text=On Wednesday the 8th of [[Bhadra (month)|Bhadon]] Badi, [[Saka Era|Saka]] 1481 (A.D. 1559) [[Rohini (nakshatra)|Rohini Nakshatra]] (i.e. the moon in the Rohini mansion) being an auspicious day, Drabya Shah aided by Bhagirath Panth, [[Ganesh Pandey|Ganesa Pande]], Gangaram Rana, Busal Arjyal, Khanal Bohra and Murli Khawas of Gorkha, concealed himself in a hut. Ganesa Pande had collected all the people of who wore the brahmanical thread such as the [[Thapa]]s, Busals, Ranas and Maski Ranas of the Magar tribe, they went by the Dahya Gauda route and the Durbar. Drabya Shah killed the [[Khadka]] [[Raja]]{{refn|group=note|[[Khadka]] [[Raja]] belonged to [[Khas]] tribe.{{sfn|Wright|1877|p=278}}}} his own hand, with a sword, during the battle ensued. At the same auspicious moment Drabya took his seat on the [[throne|gaddi]], amidst the clash music.|source=History of Nepaul{{sfn|Wright|1877|p=278}}}} Previously, the local Ghale people had chosen their king from the winners of an annual running race. Dravya Shah was not a physically robust man but he tricked his way to the win. He was backed by the Bhattarai, Aryal, Adhikari, Pant and Acharya clans who were [[Brahmin]]. By 1570, when Dravya Shah died, the running race was but a memory among the people. Dravya Shah used the army of the [[Magar people|Magar]] (an ancient tribe of [[Nepal]]) to invade neighboring states and his successors continued this aggression to increase the territory belonging to Gorkha. ''Kaji'' Ganesh Pande was his first minister of Gorkha.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} == Absolute monarchy (1768–1846) == [[File:Prithvi Narayan Shah.jpg|thumb|King [[Prithvi Narayan Shah]], the last king of [[Gorkha Kingdom]] (1743-1768) and the first Shah king of [[Nepal]] (1768-1775)]] In 1743, [[Prithvi Narayan Shah]] became the ruler of Gorkha. He declared war with other principalities, defeating them one by one. In September 1768, he established the [[Unification of Nepal|unified kingdom of Gorkha]]. He became the first [[List of monarchs of Nepal|king of large Gorkha Kingdom]]. He, his sons and their successors continued fighting and defeating other kingdoms and enlarging the kingdom of Gorkha. In 1814, the [[Anglo–Nepalese War]] between [[Kingdom of Gorkha|Gorkha]] and the [[East India Company]] began. By 1815, the Shah king had been thoroughly defeated. By 1816, Gorkha had lost one-third of its territory. The Shah kings continued to rule as an absolute monarch until 1946 when the political order changed from [[absolute monarchy]] to a [[constitutional monarchy]]. == Hereditary prime ministers (1846–1951) == In 1846, the [[Rana dynasty]] gained power in Nepal. The Ranas became prime ministers and reduced the King's status to a figurehead position. The Ranas ruled Nepal as hereditary prime ministers though in the name of the figurehead king. In 1950, the Shah king [[Tribhuvan of Nepal|King Tribhuvan]] was forced into exile in India. He and his family, including the crown prince [[Mahendra of Nepal|Mahendra]], were saved. After India became a [[secular state]] in 1950, and the remaining rajas retired, Nepal was the only remaining [[Hinduism|Hindu]] kingdom. In 1951, with the help of India, a popular politician common man [[Matrika Prasad Koirala]] became the prime minister of Nepal. Tribhuvan returned to Kathmandu. The Shah dynasty regained control and the prime minister, [[Mohan Shamsher Jang Bahadur Rana]], resigned. [[Tribhuvan of Nepal|King Tribhuvan]] ruled until 1955 and King [[Mahendra of Nepal|Mahendra]] ruled until 1972. Mahendra's son, [[Birendra of Nepal|Birendra]], became king. == Constitutional monarchy (1990–2008) == [[File:Birendra Bir Bikram Shah.jpg|thumb|King [[Birendra Bir Bikram Shah]]; the first constitutional monarch of Nepal]] In 1990, under King [[Birendra of Nepal|Birendra]], Nepal became a [[constitutional monarchy]]. King Birendra believed in cooperation between the absolute power of the monarchy and democratic governance. His brother, [[Gyanendra of Nepal|Gyanendra]] and his wife [[Aishwarya of Nepal|Queen Aishwarya]] staunchly opposed this.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} === Murder of the royal family === On 1 June 2001, a number of members of the Shah dynasty were [[Nepalese royal massacre|murdered in the royal palace]]. A High Commission report concluded that the royal family was slaughtered by Crown Prince [[Dipendra of Nepal|Dipendra]]. This remains controversial.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} Among the dead were the Crown Prince's father, King Birendra and his brother, [[Prince Nirajan of Nepal|Prince Nirajan]]. After the attack, Dipendra was in a coma and was declared king for a short time. He died a few days later. [[Gyanendra of Nepal|Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev]], Dipendra's uncle, took the throne. In February 2005, he dismissed the parliament in order to govern in his own right. == Abolition of the Shah monarchy == On 24 December 2007, the [[Nepalese Constituent Assembly]] met. It was decided by majority vote that the monarchy would be abolished in 2008 after the [[Nepalese Constituent Assembly election, 2008|Constituent Assembly election]]s.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/7158670.stm "Nepalese monarchy to be abolished."] BBC 24 December 2007 Accessed 25 December 2007. On 28 May 2008, the Assembly declared Nepal a Federal Democratic Republic and the monarchy was abolished, removing the Shah dynasty from power. Kul Bahadur Gurung said of the 601 member assembly, 560 voted in favour, 4 were against and 37 were absent or abstained.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} After this Assembly agreement involving the [[Nepali Congress]], the [[Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist–Leninist)]] and the [[Unified Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)|Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)]], Gyanendra stepped down. Gyanendra vacated his palace in [[Kathmandu]] which later became a museum. Until they could find permanent accommodation, the royal couple were offered residence as commoners at the Nagarjuna Palace, a former royal summer residence. The Nagarjuna palace lies in forested hills about eight kilometres (five miles) northwest of Kathmandu. ==Monarchs of Shah dynasty (1559–2008)== ===Monarchs of Shah dynasty of Gorkha (1559-1768) === The following is list of all ten kings of Gorkha hill principality http://www.royalark.net/Nepal/nepal2.htmhttp://www.royalark.net/Nepal/nepal3.htmhttp://www.royalark.net/Nepal/nepal4.htm {{Succession table monarch | name1 = '''[[Dravya Shah]]''' | nickname1 = | native1 = राजा द्रव्य शाह | life1 = died 1570 | reignstart1 = 1559 | reignend1 = 1570 | notes1 = Son of [[Yasho Brahma Shah]] | family1 = Shah | image1 = | alt1 = Dravya Shah of Gorkha | name2 = '''[[Purna Shah]]'''/Purendra Shah | nickname2 = | native2 = पूर्ण शाह/ पूरेन्द्र शाह | life2 = died 1605 | reignstart2 = 1570 | reignend2 = 1605 | notes2 = Son of Dravya Shah | family2 = Shah | image2 = |alt2 =Purendra Shah of Gorkha | name3 = '''[[Chatra Shah]]''' | nickname3 = | native3 = छत्र शाह | life3 = died 1609 (heirless) | reignstart3 = 1605 | reignend3 = 1609 | notes3 = First son of Purendra/Purna Shah | family3 = Shah | image3 = | alt3 = Chatra Shah of Gorkha | name4 = '''[[Ram Shah]]''' | nickname4 = Ram Shah The Just | native4 = श्रीमन्त महाराजधिराज राम शाह | life4 = died 1636 | reignstart4 = 1609 | reignend4 = 1633 (abdicated) | notes4 = Second son of Purna/Purendra Shah
